info.name: Auth-API-Springboot
info.description:
### üì¨ Postman Collection

A comprehensive collection of **requests and sample responses** for testing and exploring the endpoints of the `auth-api-springboot` project.

This collection is designed to help developers and testers quickly understand the behavior of each API route, including authentication flows, user management, token operations, and more.

It includes:

- ‚úÖ User registration and login
    
- üîê Email verification and token-based authentication
    
- üîÅ Token refresh and validation
    
- üë§ Role-based and admin-level actions
    
- üîÑ Password reset functionality
    

> <p >üí° Import the collection into Postman and start testing right away. Environment variables are included for convenience.</p>

item.name: Email id validation
item.description:
An AJAX request can be sent to the API to validate an email address. The validation checks include:

- ‚úÖ Whether the email is in a valid format
    
- üåê Whether the domain is valid
    
- üîÅ Whether the email is already registered
    
- üö´ Whether the email field is empty
    

This helps ensure early feedback during user registration or login workflows.

item.name: User name validation
item.description:
An AJAX request can be sent to the API to validate a username. The validation checks include:

- üö´ Whether the username field is empty
    
- üîÅ Whether the username is already taken
    
- ‚úÖ Whether the username is available for registration
    

This enables real-time feedback during the sign-up process.

item.name: Password Policy validation

response.name: Response

item.description:
This validates the password against the defined policy:

**Password must be at least 8 characters long and include at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter, one digit, and one special character.**

Real-time validation helps ensure users create strong, secure passwords during registration or password reset.

response.name: Response
Response

item.description:
### üìù User Registration

This endpoint handles **user registration** and performs comprehensive validation, including:

- üìß Email format and availability
    
- üë§ Username availability and format
    
- üîí Password strength (based on the defined policy)
    
- ‚úÖ Matching of `password` and `confirmPassword` fields
    

If validation fails, the response includes clear **error messages** along with corresponding **error codes**, as demonstrated in the examples below. If the validation is successful it registers the user and sends an email. In case the mail server is down the user will not be registere and an error message will be sent as given in the example below.

item.name: Email Activation

response.name: Response
Response

item.description:
### ‚úâÔ∏è Email Activation

This endpoint handles **email verification** after registration.  
  
A unique activation token is sent to the user's email as part of the verification link.

When the user clicks the link:

- üîê The token is validated
    
- ‚úÖ The user is marked as _active_ in the database
    
- üì© A response message is returned indicating success or failure (e.g., expired or invalid token)
    

This step is essential to prevent unauthorized or spam registrations.

item.name: Login request

response.name: Response

item.description:
### üîê User Login

This endpoint handles **user authentication** with the following validations:

- üìß Verifies email format and existence
    
- üîë Checks password validity
    
- ‚úÖ Confirms if the user is approved and email is verified
    
- üõ°Ô∏è Protects against brute-force attacks by locking the account after repeated failed attempts
    

Upon successful login, a **JWT token** is generated and returned in the response. This token is used to authorize subsequent requests.

> <p >üîí Secure login flow ensures both user safety and application integrity.</p>

item.description:
### üë• Admin: Manage Users

These endpoints are part of the **user management** module and require a valid **JWT token**. Only users with the **admin role** are authorized to access them.

#### üîç Find Pending Users

- üîê Validates the JWT token from the login response
    
- üßë‚Äçüíº Ensures the requester has admin privileges
    
- üìã Returns a list of users who are **pending approval** (not yet activated)
    

Admins can use this list to review user applications and manage onboarding.

üö´ Requests from non-admin users will receive a **400 Forbidden** response.

---

#### ‚úèÔ∏è Update User

- üõ†Ô∏è Allows admins to **update user status** (e.g., approve/reject)
    
- üîÑ Supports assigning or modifying **user roles**
    

This endpoint enables full control over user lifecycle and access levels.

item.name: Forgot Password
item.description:
### üîë Forgot Password

This endpoint initiates the **password reset flow** for users who have forgotten their password.

- üìß Accepts a valid, registered email address
    
- üîê Generates a secure password reset token
    
- ‚úâÔ∏è Sends an email containing the reset link with the token embedded
    

The token can then be used in the **Reset Password** endpoint to securely update the password.

> <p >‚ö†Ô∏è If the email is not registered or is invalid, a generic success message is still returned to prevent information disclosure.</p>

item.name: Reset Password

response.name: Response
Response

item.description:
üîÅ **Reset Password Token Validation**  
  
This endpoint validates the password reset token when the user clicks the reset link in their email.

üîé Checks the validity and expiry of the reset token  
  
‚úÖ If valid, returns a response indicating the token is valid and the frontend can display the password change form  
  
‚ùå If invalid or expired, returns an error response (see example below)

---

üîí **Change Password**  
  
This endpoint allows the user to update their password using the valid reset token.

üì® Accepts the new password along with the reset token  
  
üîê Updates the user's password securely  
  
üõë Marks the token as used to prevent reuse

  

‚ö†Ô∏è If the token is invalid or already used, an appropriate error message is returned to ensure security.
